attributes.title: The Effect of Photographic Affect on Charitable Donations

q1.value: The Effect of Photographic Affect on Charitable Donations

q2.value: William Sasine | Sam Williams | Daniel Nielson

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Charitable donations are an essential part of development. As nonprofit organizations continue to increase in size and influence, they require continued funding to finance their activities. A significant portion of charitable organizations’ budgets go towards marketing so that they can sustain this growth (Small and Verrochi, 2009). For a charitable organization to succeed, it is increasingly important for these organizations to identify the most effective and efficient ways to solicit donations from the general public. The rapid expansion of the internet has made digital advertising using audio-visual and textual-visual techniques especially prolific. Yet despite the growing importance of donations and the effectiveness of donation solicitation techniques in development, there is much that is still unknown or unexplored regarding this relationship. Photographs are one of the simplest yet most powerful ways of generating a profound affective response in individual viewers. Our study will attempt to enhance the discussion of the use of photography as a solicitation strategy and its perceived and actual effectiveness in obtaining financial donations. Specifically, the research question we attempt to answer will be: “How does the type of photograph that charitable organizations use in their donation materials affect an individual’s willingness to make a charitable donation?” We will test these relationships through a randomized control trial (RCT) where subjects are randomly exposed to a UNICEF brochure with either negatively-charged photographs of Ugandan poverty or positively-charged photographs of typical Ugandan life. After looking at the brochure, participants will be asked how much they would be willing to donate to UNICEF, or how much they think others would be willing to donate based on the same brochure. Significant results in favor of either category of photograph will explain which type of picture evokes a greater desire to make a financial donation. The results of this study will therefore prove beneficial for charities and nonprofit organizations, who can use these findings to determine how best to use photographs as promotional and informational tools to solicit donations. The findings will also help explain possible discrepancies between the type of image people think should earn donations and the type of image that actually does.

q16.value: We hypothesize that subjects exposed to uplifting positive-affect photographs depicting typical Ugandan life will be more likely to donate to a corresponding charitable organization than subjects who are shown images of Ugandan poverty, which will induce negative affect. We hypothesize this because stark images of poverty ought to create a sense of hopelessness about the intractability of poverty in general and therefore are expected to dampen charitable giving. We further hypothesize that the second group of participants, who will be asked to predict the donations of others, will predict greater donations for the poverty photos than for the photos that induce positive affect, precisely the opposite of what we predict for the actual donations. We predict that this will occur because it is fairly standard practice to use poverty as a means of evoking emotion in potential donors. Therefore, people will expect images of Ugandan poverty to have a larger effect than images of Ugandan life because they conform to conventional expectations in evoking a greater emotional response to the plight of the global poor.

q17.value: This study will test how potential donors respond to development-related photographs of varying content. More specifically, we will measure how likely our subjects will be to donate to a specific charity after being exposed to different types of photographs. To test this, subjects will be given a survey presenting one of two types of randomly assigned photographs: one group of photographs will depict typical Ugandan life – images of native Ugandans in everyday situations evincing positive affect – and the other will depict typical Ugandan poverty – stark images depicting instances of famine and poverty that exists in the region. After viewing the photographs, a randomly assigned pool of subjects will be asked how much of their potential $100 lottery winnings they would be willing to donate to UNICEF should they win the $100 bonus pay. The other half of the subject pool will be asked how much they believe other people would be willing to donate in each condition. The survey will ask all participants relevant demographic data that we can subsequently use as control variables in a regression model.

attributes.title: Cooperation across ideological divide: Post-conflict reconciliation in Korea

q1.value: Cooperation across ideological divide: Post-conflict reconciliation in Korea

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Prolonged ideologically-motivated civil conflicts are relatively common, and they tend to leave a cultural legacy of division. Is there a way to engender closer cooperation between conflicting groups once reconciliation is in sight? That is the question that we ask in this project. Drawing on the literature on common ingroup identity theory in psychology (Gaertner and Dovidio 2000; Gaertner et al. 1993) we ask whether an appeal to historical commonalities that predate the most recent conflict might be effective in papering over the divisions and thus leading to enhanced cooperation. This is a question that has received surprisingly little attention in the literature on postconflict reconciliation, which tends to focus on the effectiveness of various economic interventions on interpersonal rather than intergroup cooperation (Attanasio et al. 2015; Avdeenko and Gilligan 2015; Fearon et al. 2009, 2015; Nguyen and Rieger 2017). Whereas the substantial literature on intergroup cooperation focuses primarily on interactions across racial, ethnic, or religious boundaries (Balliet et al. 2014; Goldenberg et al. 2017; Pagotto et al. 2013; Pettigrew and Tropp 2006; Reuben and Tyran 2010; Scacco and Warren 2018), leaving unexplored postconflict reconciliation among culturally distinctive but racially, ethnically, or religiously homogeneous groups. The common ingroup identity theory had received some attention in political science in recent years, but its insights are ordinarily tested on outcomes such as prejudice and altruism in intergroup interactions (Charnysh et al. 2015; Lazarev and Sharma 2017; Levendusky 2018). Some work has been done on the effectiveness of appeals to common ingroup identity on cooperation (Chang and Peisakhin 2019; Robinson 2016) but in the context other than the aftermath of a protracted ideological conflict. To the best of our knowledge, ours will be the first experimental study to test the theory in that important context. Another insight that we plan to borrow from psychology has to do with possible differential effects of appeals to common ingroup identity on different types of groups. Social psychologists have long recognized that group status, as a product of group size, economic influence, or social hierarchy, can diminish or augment intergroup bias or cooperation levels (Brewer et al. 1993; Dovidio et al. 2008; Ellemers et al. 1992; Hogg and Hains 1996; Tajfel and Turner 1979). In political science, there is relatively little empirical work on how appeals to common superordinate identity are moderated by group status (see Shayo 2009, Charnysh et al. 2015), and this is another area where we hope to make a contribution.

q16.value: H1: Exposure to a video on historical commonalities will increase out-group favoritism, relative trust in outgroup members, and cooperation levels. H2: Discussion on historical commonalities further increases out-group favoritism, relative trust in outgroup members, and cooperation. H3: The effect of the common superordinate identity on members of a socially dominant group increases as they more positively perceive out-group members. H4: The effect of the common superordinate identity is weaker among members of a socially dominant group, compared to those from a socially low-status group.

q17.value: There will be two sets of six-person teams in this study. One set of teams will be composed of three South Koreans and three North Koreans. The other of three South Koreans and three Chinese Koreans. Variation in the composition of teams is designed to get at variable cooperation under the condition where the cooperating partner is of different social status. Those assigned to the commonality prime delivered in a pre-recorded 10-minute video will be asked to watch the video before participating in tasks that measure cooperation across group lines. The video will discuss Korea’s struggle for independence under Japanese colonial rule. Those subject to the team discussion prime will first watch the same video and will then be asked to comment on its content and on related issues of common Korean historical identity, Japan’s responsibility for victimizing the Korean population, and the issue of possible reparations for the descendants of the original victims of colonial brutality. Team discussion will be lightly moderated by trained moderators and will last for 20-30 minutes. For those in the team discussion treatment the video serves as a prime to guide the subsequent discussion. Those in the baseline condition will neither watch the video nor engage in team discussion. The effectiveness of the expert video will be determined by comparing cooperation levels among those who watched the video to those in the baseline condition. In contrast, to back out the effectiveness of team discussion we will compare the results of that treatment to cooperation levels in the video intervention; this will allow us to hold constant exposure to the video. Prior to being assigned to a team, participants will be asked to complete a pre-treatment questionnaire in which we will collect demographic information and data on attitudes toward North and South Korea, the North Korean refugees, Chinese Koreans, and information about the participants’ knowledge of pre-1945 Korean history. In addition, participants will be asked about their perceptions of other groups participating in the experiment, and, specifically, whether they hold other groups in high regard. This information will be used to test the mechanisms by which cooperation is engendered across group boundaries. After completing the survey, participants will be randomly assigned to teams, and teams randomly assigned to the three interventions. After that, those in the baseline condition will proceed immediately to behavioral games that are commonly used to measure ingroup/outgroup favoritism, intra/intergroup trust, and cooperation. Meanwhile, those assigned to the video and video + discussion intervention will watch the video and, if relevant, discuss it in their mixed teams before playing the behavioral games. The games are explained in more detail in the section on measurements. After completing the games, participants will be asked to fill out a brief post-treatment survey testing their level of understanding of the tasks, receptiveness to the treatments, and level of comfort with the study’s tasks. They will then be compensated for their participation – gains from the public goods games will be awarded to participants – and will depart.

q19.value: 504 in total: 252 South Koreans, 126 North Korean refugees, and 126 Chinese Koreans

attributes.title: Altruism, trust and right-wing support in the presence of newcomers: Eastern Germany after the refugee crisis

q1.value: Altruism, trust and right-wing support in the presence of newcomers: Eastern Germany after the refugee crisis

q2.value: Max Schaub | Johanna Gereke | Delia Baldassarri

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: How does first-time, local, sustained exposure to foreign newcomers affect altruism and cooperation towards immigrants and natives? And how does such exposure shape anti-immigrant sentiments and voting behavior? To address these questions, we study the recent arrival of refugees in East-Germany, a region that had not previously experienced any consistent influx of foreigners. Exploiting the random allocation of refugees to localities, we aim at comparing attitudes and behavior of native Germans living in localities that have received an influx of refugees, to localities that were not touched by this experience. We aim to make two contributions. First, we speak to the social-psychological debate on the effects of inter-group contact on altruism and trust. Altruism and trust – or ‘mutual regard’ – are seen as important ingredients of a nations economic and social well-being, but also as phenomena particularly challenged by increasing levels of immigration (Arrow, 1974; Collier, 2013; Alesina and Ferrara, 2000; Gambetta, 1988). In the literature, several conflicting hypotheses co-exist how contact should influence altruism and trust. On the one hand, the contact hypothesis predicts that, under favourable conditions, contact tends to improve intercommunal relationships (Allport, 1954; Pettigrew and Tropp, 2006). In stark contrast to this, the conflict hypothesis predicts that exposure will increase levels of competition between groups, will trigger fears among the established native populations, and will hence lead to a rejection of ethnic ‘others’ and newcomers (Bobo and Hutchings, 1996; Quillian, 1996; Olzak, 1992). A third theory specifies that increased intergroup competition following the arrival of newcomers may cause parochial altruism – a combination of hostility towards these newcomers combined with increased ingroup solidarity and trust (Bowles and Gintis, 2004; Halevy et al., 2008; Abbink et al., 2012). The continuing coexistence of these opposed hypotheses is puzzling, and is partly due to problems of measurement and endogeneity that have vexed scholars studying the effects of outgroup exposure. Second, we aim to contribute to an ongoing debate in political science how immigration and the reception of refugees shape political attitudes and behavior. A large number of studies show that immigration is a highly salient topic effectively mobilizing voters, especially on the political right (Sniderman et al., 2004; Dustmann and Preston, 2007; Brader et al., 2008; Dancygier, 2010; Hainmueller and Hopkins, 2014; Abrajano and Hajnal, 2015). Questions of immigration, the hosting of refugees and citizenship have become even more politicized in recent years with the steady rise of right-wing populists politicians and parties, which reached first peaks in 2016, with the election of Donald Trump as US president and the successful ‘Brexit’ referendum in the UK to leave the EU. In Germany, this rightward shift in politics is reflected in the success of the Alternative für Deutschland (‘Alternative for Germany’)/ AfD party, which first entered 14 out of 16 regional parliaments, and in the 2017 federal elections acceded to the national parliament as the third-strongest party. As with the support for Trump in the US, the AfD garnered their best results in relatively rural and underdeveloped regions of country. The success of right-wing politicians and parties and the geographical pattern of their support are often attributed to the relative demise in status of members of the working class, who feel cut out from increasingly deregulated national economies, and feel alienated by high levels of immigration and the dominance of cosmopolitan values (Hochschild, 2016; Gest, 2016; Gidron and Hall, 2017; Inglehart and Norris, 2016; Colantone and Stanig, 2017; Rodrik, 2017). We contribute to this debate by testing how first-time, sustained exposure to foreign newcomers – in combination with cues regarding the religious affiliation of the newcomers and the relative economic situation of the hosting population – shape right-wing attitudes and voting behavior.

q16.value: We will record two types of outcomes: 1) altruism, trust and discriminatory behavior towards immigrants and natives, measured with a set of behavioral games, and 2) (right-wing) attitudes and voting behavior, measured in terms of recalled and prospective voting decisions and survey items. Altruism, trust and discrimination Altruism will be measured in terms of decisions in a dictator game, a widely used measure of altruism (Kahneman et al., 1986; Camerer, 2003; Fershtman and Gneezy, 2001). In the dictator game, the respondent is given a fixed amount of money and asked if s/he is will to share parts or all of it with a matched partner. The share handed over to the partner is interpreted as a measure of altruism. Our respondents will play the DG twice, once with a generic German native (either man or women), and once with a generic immigrant (either man or women). The native/immigrant status will be indicated by the name of the partner and a photo. The photos will be supplied by actors hired for that purpose. Trust will be measured with a version of the trust game (Berg et al., 1995). In the trust game, two players are endowed with a fixed amount of money. The first player is then asked whether s/he would like to send part or all of his/her endowment to his/her partner. Whatever the first player sends is multiplied by the experimenter, usually by a factor of 2 or 3. The partner/second player can now decide whether and how much of the received amount to return to the first player. Sending money therefore is a potentially profitable but risky decision for the first player, matching the widely accepted definition of a trusting decision (Gambetta, 1988). The share of the original endowment sent will be interpreted as the measure of trust. Again, participants will engage in the trust game twice, once when matched with the generic native partner, and once when matched with the generic immigrant partner. Both times, participants will decide in the role of the first player. In order to measure discrimination, we include a division game (Peterson, 2016). In the game, participants are given a fixed amount of money and are asked to distribute that amount to two partners (cp. Habyarimana et al., 2009). They can choose any split they like, dividing the amount equally, allocating the whole amount to one partner only, or choosing some intermediate solution. In our game, in all cases the two partners in this game will consist of a generic native and a generic immigrant. The extent to which the split favors one or another is interpreted as a measure of discrimination. Right-wing populism and attitudes towards immigrants and voting behavior Support for anti-immigrant and other (populist) right-wing positions will be measured with a number of survey items, tapping both into attitudes and political behavior. The main behavioral measure will be a recall of the party-choice (Zweitstimme) during the 2017 general elections. We are particularly interested in vote choices for the AfD – Germany’s upstart right-wing populist party – vs. others. As a further behavioral measure, will also include a petition urging the federal government to outlaw dual citizenship – a prominent concern of the political right in Germany. Participants will be asked to indicate their support or opposition to this petition. In addition, we will include a number of survey items used in other studies probing for right-wing attitudes and attitudes towards refugees (cp. Best et al., 2016; Gerhards et al., 2016). We will analyze the items separately and in combination by standardizing and averaging all items. All questions are listed in Appendix II.

q17.value: Given the above, we will start our analysis with a simple model regressing the outcomes of interest on an indicator for exposure to refugees. To check whether ‘treatment dosage’ plays a role, in other specifications we will use a categorical or continuous indicator – the number of refugees hosted in a municipality – as independent variable instead of the binary indicator.

q27.value: Natural experiment; allocation of refugees by state authorities according to bureaucratic rules

They can choose any split they like, dividing the amount equally, allocating the whole amount to one partner only, or choosing some intermediate solution. In our game, in all cases the two partners in this game will consist of a generic native and a generic immigrant. The extent to which the split favors one or another is interpreted as a measure of discrimination. Right-wing populism and attitudes towards immigrants and voting behavior Support for anti-immigrant and other (populist) right-wing positions will be measured with a number of survey items, tapping both into attitudes and political behavior. The main behavioral measure will be a recall of the party-choice (Zweitstimme) during the 2017 general elections. We are particularly interested in vote choices for the AfD – Germany’s upstart right-wing populist party – vs. others. As a further behavioral measure, will also include a petition urging the federal government to outlaw dual citizenship – a prominent concern of the political right in Germany. Participants will be asked to indicate their support or opposition to this petition. In addition, we will include a number of survey items used in other studies probing for right-wing attitudes and attitudes towards refugees (cp. Best et al., 2016; Gerhards et al., 2016). We will analyze the items separately and in combination by standardizing and averaging all items. All questions are listed in Appendix II.
registration_responses.q17: Given the above, we will start our analysis with a simple model regressing the outcomes of interest on an indicator for exposure to refugees. To check whether ‘treatment dosage’ plays a role, in other specifications we will use a categorical or continuous indicator – the number of refugees hosted in a municipality – as independent variable instead of the binary indicator.
registration_responses.q27: Natural experiment; allocation of refugees by state authorities according to bureaucratic rules

attributes.title: Teargas and Selfie Cams: Foreign Protests and Media in the Digital Age

q1.value: Teargas and Selfie Cams: Foreign Protests and Media in the Digital Age

q2.value: Ze Fu | Naima Green-Riley | Dominika Kruszewska

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In this paper, we use a survey experiment to explore if 1) repression of pro-democracy protesters abroad by authorities increases public support for US intervention on their behalf and 2) if the source of the information about repression influences the levels of support. In short, if activists can garner support for their movement by exposing the state violence to which they fall victim, should they do so via traditional media or can they use a new media platform? Can new media deliver on its promise or does an increase in access and visibility come at the cost of credibility?

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 (repression): Public support for U.S. action to help the protesters and interest in learning more about the situation will increase if the movement is violently repressed by security forces. Hypothesis 2 (media and repression): Public support for U.S. action to help the protesters and interest in learning more about the situation will increase if the movement is violently repressed by security forces and the video source is a selfie cam. When protests are not violently repressed, there will be no effect of the media source on support or interest. Hypothesis 3 (blame): Respondents in the cell phone footage condition will be more likely to blame the government and/or the security forces, not the protesters, for the escalation of the situation. Hypothesis 4 (trust): We expect both the repression and the source of the footage to influence the levels of respondents' trust in the content of the video but we not do have any prior beliefs about the direction of the effects.

q17.value: The study will use data from an online survey experiment fielded on Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk). In the experiment, participants will be randomly assigned to one of four experimental conditions. Respondents in each experimental condition will be asked to watch a brief video and told (truthfully) that it shows a recent protest in a foreign country calling for more democratic governance, but no further description will be provided. There will be four short (about 25 seconds each) treatment videos used in the study, each featuring real footage of protests in Venezuela. The elements that will vary are response of the police (violent or nonviolent) and the media source (recognized media organization v. cellphone footage from a private individual). The media source will be varied in two ways: first, written information on the source of the video and second, the visual appearance of the video recording. After watching the video, participants will answer a few questions about their support for potential actions U.S. government could take in support of the protesters, their assessment of the situation, and be given an option to learn more about the protests.

When protests are not violently repressed, there will be no effect of the media source on support or interest. attributes.title: The Mechanism, Extent and Effects of Fiscal Illusion Among UK Taxpayers

q1.value: The Mechanism, Extent and Effects of Fiscal Illusion Among UK Taxpayers

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Fiscal illusion theory suggests that taxpayers may be unaware of their taxes and how their taxes are spent. Empirical research on the hypotheses of fiscal illusion has been inconclusive, while taxpayers' perception studies have reported widespread tax misperception, with both over and underestimation observed. The chief aims of proposed research are to: - investigate the mechanism of fiscal illusion, allowing for an updated typology of fiscal illusion, - gather data on UK taxpayer's perception of their total taxes, - examine how the provision of information on their total taxes and the allocation of taxes affects UK taxpayers' fiscal policy preferences. The main research questions are: 1. How accurately do taxpayers perceive their taxes and costs of public services? 2. How does taxpayers' knowledge of their comprehensive taxes and costs of public services affect their tax and public spending preferences? 3. How does the mechanism of fiscal illusion work? Mixed methods research is proposed to answer the questions on the mechanism of fiscal illusion and UK taxpayers' perception of their taxes and contribution to public expenditure. The explanatory sequential design will consist of quantitative data collection (through a web survey-based experiment) in the first stage and qualitative data collection (through interviews) in the second stage. This pre-registration is relevant for the first stage of the project, the web survey-based experiment.

q16.value: H1: Taxpayers misperceive their total tax burden. H2: Revealing the amount of taxes paid by individuals will have an effect on their tax policy preferences. H3: Revealing the burden imposed by different taxes on individuals will change their relative approval for different taxes. H4: Revealing the actual cost of public services incurred by individuals will affect their public spending preferences. H5: Revealing the amount of taxes paid, and the cost of public services incurred by individuals will affect their perception of tax fairness. H6: Revealing the amount of taxes paid, and the costs of public services incurred by individuals will make it easier for them to form fiscal policy preferences. H7: Revealing how much individuals paid in tax and contributed to public services will reduce alienation.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested through a web survey-based randomized experiment. The data will be collected through a structured web survey, where a representative sample of UK taxpayers will be randomly divided into a control and a treatment group. The treatment group will be provided with its personalized annual tax statement and estimated costs of public services. The control group will not receive such details on their tax and public spending. The data provided by the respondents of both groups will allow for the calculation of the taxes paid by the respondents, and their allocation to public services. Both the treatment and the control groups will be asked identical pretest questions on their perception of taxes, and identical posttest questions on their tax and public spending preferences, including their attitudes towards tax fairness.

registration_responses.q1: The Mechanism, Extent and Effects of Fiscal Illusion Among UK Taxpayers
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

attributes.title: Salience of political identity and social attitudes II - A second test during an election campaign

q1.value: Salience of political identity and social attitudes II - A second test during an election campaign

q5.value: The research is supported by the grant K 120070 of NKFIH (Hungarian public research funding agency). Comments by Marcel van Assen and Gabor Hajdu are greatfully acknowledged.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: A question investigated in the literature: the effects of opinions of political elite groups on voters’ attitudes towards contested policy issues. My aim is to construct a test of identity-based political attitude adjustment which excludes the alternative hypotheses based on rational learning or motivated reasoning. I had carried out a first test of identity-based political attitude adjustment in January 2018, just before a parliamentary election campaign started in mid-February. It was a registered study (http://egap.org/registration/3041). The findings are mostly in line with the hypotheses. In this new study, I intend to a) partly replicate the experiment in the context of an election campaign; b) test the effect of a treatment where the salience of political identity is intended to be decreased (relative to the control group). (Elections will be held on 8 April 2018 in Hungary.) (For more details see: http://egap.org/registration-details/3041)

q16.value: H1 The significant increase of salience of political identity, on average, will increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community on a politicized question. (A replication) H2 The increase of situational salience of political identity will not increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community on a non-politicized policy question (A replication) H3 The increase of salience of political identity will not increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community among politically extremely lowly and highly engaged individuals (A replication) H4 The effect of the increase of the situatinal salience of political identity on attitudes toward a politicized question in the experiment (H1) is smaller in the final weeks of an election campaign than at other times. H5 When it comes to a politicized question, the decrease of salience of political identity during the final period of an election campaign, on average, will increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustmenton in accordance with the position which is in contrast with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community. H6 H5 does not hold among politically extremely lowly and highly engaged individuals. I present statements about two questions: one of them has been politicized in the months before the survey in Hungary, the other one hasn’t (the benefits of funding Hungarian civil organizations from abroad, and reforms giving voting rights for children).

q17.value: 1) I increase the salience of political identity in the treatment conditions by making the political conflict between various political communities salient without mentioning elite/group opinion on or conflict around the question. 2) I make political identity less salient by making the relevance of non-political identities in interpersonal relations salient.

attributes.title: When Do Policymakers Listen to Experts?

q1.value: When Do Policymakers Listen to Experts?

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In this study, I seek to identify the conditions under which policymakers update their policy preferences in response to expert-produced knowledge. I choose three policy questions based on four criteria: (1) it a policy domain specifically relevant to local policymakers, (2) there is a high degree of consensus among the relevant expert community about the efficacy of the policy, and (3) there exists a significant level of people who hold the expert-inconsistent policy preference. Finally, (4) the three issues are selected to be well-distributed in terms of whether and how party ID predicts the incidence of expert-inconsistent beliefs.

q16.value: H1. Party Symmetry Hypothesis: Whether Democrats or Republicans are more “anti-expert” depends on the issue. H2. Motivated Reasoning Hypothesis: Responsiveness to an expert message is lower when the message is dissonant. H3. Perceived Bias Hypothesis: The more the respondent believes the experts to be biased against his/her own party, the less responsive he or she will be. H4: Deference Hypothesis I: Responsiveness to expertise depends on deference to experts. H5. Party Asymmetry Hypothesis: Averaged across issues areas, republicans are more likely to believe experts are biased. H6. Deference Hypothesis II. Conditional on having low deference for experts, one can hold expert-inconsistent preferences without holding misperceptions about what experts believe.

q17.value: A series of online surveys with local and state policymakers.

Finally, (4) the three issues are selected to be well-distributed in terms of whether and how party ID predicts the incidence of expert-inconsistent beliefs.

H4: Deference Hypothesis I: Responsiveness to expertise depends on deference to experts. H5. Conditional on having low deference for experts, one can hold expert-inconsistent preferences without holding misperceptions about what experts believe.
registration_responses.q17: A series of online surveys with local and state policymakers.

attributes.title: “They’re Talking About Us”: Latino Perceptions of Implicit and Explicit Anti-Latino Appeals

q1.value: “They’re Talking About Us”: Latino Perceptions of Implicit and Explicit Anti-Latino Appeals

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This project is a survey experiment advancing research on the topic of racial cues, specifically the Implicit-Explicit model (Mendelberg 2001; Valentino, Hutchings, and White 2002). We will conduct a survey experiment presenting Latino and white respondents with a simulated election campaign advertisement from a fictional Republican candidate for Senate named Scott Ritter. Respondents will randomly be assigned to one of several experimental conditions that vary the images/language used in the advertisements and exposure to a fictional op-ed that describes the advertisement as “using the race card”. This setup draws directly from the IE model – some respondents will receive non-racial messages (control), others will receive racial messages without an op-ed (implicitly racial), and others will receive racial messages followed by an op-ed (explicitly racial). After viewing the advertisement, they will be asked about their opinion of and likelihood of voting for the candidate, their emotions in reaction to the advertisement, their perceptions about the racial content of the advertisement, their beliefs about whether the candidate is racially prejudiced, and their stance on whether such rhetoric is acceptable in American politics.

q16.value: H1: Latinos’ stronger adherence to egalitarian norms than whites will lead to lower support for candidates using anti-immigrant appeals (relative to a non-racial control appeal), and lower support for candidates using explicit anti-immigrant appeals (relative to implicit appeals). H2: Latinos’ and whites’ egalitarian attitudes will be similarly primed by explicit anti-immigrant appeals (relative to non-racial control and implicit appeals). H3: Latinos more than whites will detect and reject the inegalitarian content of implicit anti-immigrant appeals (relative to a non-racial control appeal), and they will detect and reject the inegalitarian content of explicit anti-immigrant appeals more so than implicit appeals. H4: Latinos more than whites will withdraw support from candidates using anti-immigrant appeals without policy content more so than from candidates using anti-immigrant appeals with legitimate policy content. H5. Latino in-group identity strength and perceptions of discrimination will be primed by implicit anti-immigrant appeals (relative to explicit and non-racial appeals); among whites, anti-immigrant and anti-Latino attitudes will be primed by implicit and explicit anti-immigrant appeals with policy content (relative to non-racial appeals), while these attitudes will be primed only by implicit anti-immigrant appeals without policy content (relative to explicit and non-racial appeals).

q17.value: Our primary outcomes of interest measure the level of support that each respondent has towards the candidate Scott Ritter. We first will record intent to vote for Ritter: “If Scott Ritter, the U.S. Senate candidate who was featured in the advertisement you just saw, was running in an election in your state, how likely would you be to vote for him?” The responses range from extremely likely to extremely unlikely (5-pt scale). Next, we will ask about sentiment towards Ritter as a candidate: “How favorable or unfavorable do you feel towards Scott Ritter as a Republican U.S. Senate candidate?” The answers ranged from strongly favorable to strongly unfavorable (7-pt scale). We will combine these two questions into a general Ritter support scale, which we will rescale to range between 0 and 1. Additionally, we will ask respondents about their emotional responses to the Ritter advertisement: “Now we are interested in how Ritter's political advertisement made you feel. For each of the following emotions, please tell us whether it made you feel that way a great deal, a substantial amount, a moderate amount, a little or not at all.” The responses range from a great deal to not at all (5-pt scale). The emotions we ask about include Angry, Depressed, Anxious, and Enthusiastic.

attributes.title: Just the facts? How Self-Selection Conditions Efforts to Correct Misinformation about Immigration

q1.value: Just the facts? How Self-Selection Conditions Efforts to Correct Misinformation about Immigration

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Immigration is a central issue in contemporary U.S. politics. Polling suggests that large portions of the American public are not just uninformed about immigration, but often misinformed, confidently holding factually incorrect beliefs about things like the percentage of foreign-born residents in the U.S. illegally or the ability of undocumented immigrants to receive public benefits. Research on correcting misinformation has yielded mixed results, with some studies showing corrections can yield persistent effects while others finding that corrections can sometimes lead individuals to hold their prior incorrect beliefs more strongly. This paper argues that the effects of corrections depend on who actually encounters this information. People who choose to read an article fact-checking the President's statements on immigration will respond differently from those forced to read an article they would have otherwise avoided. Using a preference-incorporating choice and assignment (PICA) design, which pairs the design of a standard survey experiment with an additional condition in which some subjects have a choice over whether to read the article, this paper estimates the effects of efforts to correct misinformation on immigration among those likely and unlikely to encounter this information. These choice-specific effects shed new light on public opinion about immigration and offer broader insights into when and why efforts to correct misinformation may succeed or fail.

q16.value: The study identifies the Average Choice-Specific Treatment Effects (ACTE) of an informational treatment fact-checking claims made by President Trump about immigration. It tests two primary hypotheses: H1-Updating among selectors: The effects among those likely to read a fact-check on immigration (ACTE-Select) will be negative, reducing the proportion of respondents who are misinformed and uninformed. H2-Backlash among avoiders: The effects among those unlikely to read a fact-check on immigration (ACTE-Avoid) will be positive, increasing the proportion of respondents who hold misinformed beliefs while reducing the proportion of respondents who are either informed or uninformed.

q17.value: I test these hypotheses by estimating ACTEs from the PICA design, with standard errors constructed via bootstrapping.

registration_responses.q17: I test these hypotheses by estimating ACTEs from the PICA design, with standard errors constructed via bootstrapping.

attributes.title: Extrinsic, Intrinsic, and Social Incentives for Crowdsourcing Development Information in Uganda: A Field Experiment

q1.value: Extrinsic, Intrinsic, and Social Incentives for Crowdsourcing Development Information in Uganda: A Field Experiment

q2.value: Sean M. Blaschke | Peter Carroll | Daniela Rojas Chaves | Mike Findley | Madeleine Gleave | Kaylee B Hodgson | Robert N. Morello | Daniel Nielson | Rebecca Russavage

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: In this experiment, we compare two social motivations for participating in U-Report with an extrinsic material reward: the promise of entry in a lottery to win a solar mobile phone charger.

q16.value: 1. We hypothesize that all three interventions (human response, response lottery, and thematic network) will significantly improve increase and improve engagement on the U-Report platform (response rates, average number of responses, and the quality of responses). 2. We expect human feedback to have the most significant impact on the level and specifically the quality of responses.

q17.value: These interventions were randomly assigned by district to U-Reporters who had already enrolled in the system. The response rates and quality of responses were measured and recorded for each U-Reporter in the experiment. The experiment measures the success of the interventions by evaluating how they affected the outcome measures. We plan to employ the following analyses to evaluate the success of our treatments: 1. Difference-in-means tests using randomization inference to evaluate how the different treatments (control, human response, response lottery, and thematic network) affect response rates. 2. Difference-in-means test using randomization inference to evaluate how the different treatments (control, human response, response lottery, and thematic network) affect the average number of responses per person. 3. Difference-in-means test using randomization inference to evaluate how the different treatments (control, human response, response lottery, and thematic network) affect the quality of responses. 4. Linear regression with covariates (see below) to test robustness for tests of how the different treatments affect response rates. 5. Linear regression with covariates (see below) to test robustness for tests of how the different treatments affect average number of response per person. 6. Linear regression with covariates (see below) to test robustness for tests of how the different treatments affect the quality of responses. 7. Two-stage regression to estimate the treatment effect on the treated or complier average causal effect (CACE) to test how different treatments affect the quality of a response given that the subject responded at all.
